unnormalised: Okay, here's the blog post you requested, focusing on fuel measurements in a narrative tone, incorporating Indian elements and unnormalized data as specified:
normalised: My Car and the Petrol Pump Puzzle

unnormalised: **My Car and the Petrol Pump Puzzle**
normalised: I remember the first time I ever filled up my own car. It was my dad's old Maruti eight hundred, a trusty little vehicle that had seen better days. I was maybe eighteen, just got my license, and Dad, bless his heart, was slowly letting me take the reins. The petrol gauge was blinking – a very insistent blink, I might add. So, off I went, feeling a heady mix of freedom and responsibility.

unnormalised: I remember the first time I ever filled up my own car. It was my dad's old Maruti 800, a trusty little vehicle that had seen better days. I was maybe 18, just got my license, and Dad, bless his heart, was slowly letting me take the reins. The petrol gauge was blinking – a very insistent blink, I might add. So, off I went, feeling a heady mix of freedom and responsibility.
normalised: Pulling up to the petrol pump, I was instantly overwhelmed. There were so many numbers and symbols! I vaguely remembered Dad saying something about "regular" versus "premium," but that's where my knowledge ended. I asked the pump attendant, a friendly fellow named Ramesh, "Kitna dalna hai, bhai?" How much to put in? He just smiled and said, "Aap batao, sir." You tell me, sir.

unnormalised: Pulling up to the petrol pump, I was instantly overwhelmed. There were so many numbers and symbols! I vaguely remembered Dad saying something about "regular" vs. "premium," but that's where my knowledge ended. I asked the pump attendant, a friendly fellow named Ramesh, "Kitna dalna hai, bhai?" How much to put in? He just smiled and said, "Aap batao, sir." You tell me, sir.
normalised: Panic set in. I knew the tank was practically empty. I blurted out, "rupee five hundred ka petrol!" Five hundred rupees worth of petrol. Ramesh nodded and started filling the tank. I watched, mesmerized, as the numbers on the pump whirred upward. I realised I didn't even know how much the tank held.

unnormalised: Panic set in. I knew the tank was practically empty. I blurted out, "₹500 ka petrol!" Five hundred rupees worth of petrol. Ramesh nodded and started filling the tank. I watched, mesmerized, as the numbers on the pump whirred upward. I realised I didn’t even know how much the tank held.
normalised: The display stopped at six point one five litres. Ramesh handed me the nozzle. "Ho gaya, sir." All done, sir. I paid him, feeling slightly less clueless but still very much a newbie. Over the next few weeks, I started paying more attention. I noticed the price per litre, which at the time was around rupees eighty point five zero per litre. I even started keeping a mental note of how many kilometers I got per litre.

unnormalised: The display stopped at 6.15 litres. Ramesh handed me the nozzle. "Ho gaya, sir." All done, sir. I paid him, feeling slightly less clueless but still very much a newbie. Over the next few weeks, I started paying more attention. I noticed the price per litre, which at the time was around Rs. 80.50/L. I even started keeping a mental note of how many kilometers I got per litre.
normalised: Over time, I figured out my car had a thirty five litre fuel tank. One time, I experimented and filled it to the brim, costing me rupees two thousand seven hundred and fifty, I think. It was a bit of a waste, really, carrying all that extra weight around. Later, I became more careful about fuel efficiency. I even downloaded an app to track my mileage and calculate the average consumption, usually around fifteen kilometers per litre in the city and eighteen kilometers per litre on the highway. The app showed I was spending approximately rupees four thousand per month on fuel.

unnormalised: Over time, I figured out my car had a 35L fuel tank. One time, I experimented and filled it to the brim, costing me Rs 2750, I think. It was a bit of a waste, really, carrying all that extra weight around. Later, I became more careful about fuel efficiency. I even downloaded an app to track my mileage and calculate the average consumption, usually around 15 km/L in the city and 18 km/L on the highway. The app showed I was spending approximately Rs 4000/month on fuel.
normalised: I also learned about octane ratings and how they affect performance. Dad always used regular petrol, but one day I tried "Power" – a premium fuel claiming to give better mileage. Honestly, I didn't notice much of a difference. Maybe a slight improvement, but definitely not worth the extra rupees five per litre.

unnormalised: I also learned about octane ratings and how they affect performance. Dad always used regular petrol, but one day I tried "Power" – a premium fuel claiming to give better mileage. Honestly, I didn't notice much of a difference. Maybe a slight improvement, but definitely not worth the extra Rs. 5/L.
normalised: These days, I'm a seasoned pro at the petrol pump. I know my car, I know my fuel consumption, and I even know Ramesh by name. And that blinking fuel gauge? It still gives me a jolt of responsibility, but now it's a familiar one, a reminder of how far I've come since that first, slightly panicked, petrol pump visit.

unnormalised: These days, I'm a seasoned pro at the petrol pump. I know my car, I know my fuel consumption, and I even know Ramesh by name. And that blinking fuel gauge? It still gives me a jolt of responsibility, but now it's a familiar one, a reminder of how far I've come since that first, slightly panicked, petrol pump visit.
